newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy govt makes offer in metalworkers' dispute.
newsitem.headline: Italy govt makes offer in metalworkers' dispute.

text.p: The Italian government, after all-night talks with trade unions and employers, presented a proposal on Monday to end a protracted pay dispute in the engineering and metalworkers' sector.
The talks were suspended while unions and employers studied the proposal, said the statement issued by the office of Prime Minister Romano Prodi on Monday morning.
"After several different meetings which took place overnight, the government, taking note of the significant progress that was made, presented a proposal to end the negotiations," the statement said.

Union leaders had hoped for a deal by Sunday in the months-long dispute but said earlier in the day that employers had raised fresh obstacles and called on the government to decide how to carry negotiations forward.
Talks between sectoral unions FIM, FIOM and UILM and the employers' body Federmeccanica resumed last Monday for the first time in more than a month to try to end the dispute.
It involves some 1.7 million workers in a sector which accounts for 40 percent of industrial output.
Any deal is likely to set the tone for other pay accords and prove key to Italy's hopes of containing inflation.
Prodi's office said the government had proposed a 30-month national contract period to replace a two-year contract which expired last June.

Under the proposal, the employers would make a one-time payment of 512,000 lire ($316) during the first six months, followed by graduated monthly wage increases totalling 200,000 lire ($124) during the rest of the contract, the statement said.

Union leaders said they expected to give their response to the proposal sometime later on Monday or Tuesday, and that a new meeting between the unions and Federmecanicca would likely take place on Tuesday at the Labour Ministry.
"The government has forwarded a comprehensive proposal which we are evaluating," said Sergio Cofferatti, leader of an umbrella trade group CGIL.
